titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Greene Avenue Presbyterian Church foreclosure deed 1974.235
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-09T11:06-0500

did.unittitle: Greene Avenue Presbyterian Church foreclosure deed

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Greene Avenue Presbyterian Church foreclosure deed, 1974.235, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The collection was formally accessioned in 1974.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Greene Avenue Presbyterian Church was organized in 1874.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One deed between Thomas M. Riley, Sheriff of Kings County, and William P. Earle of New York City, granting Earle a portion of the property occupied by the Greene Avenue Presbyterian Church due to foreclosure. The deed was created in 1880 and was recorded in the Kings County Register's Office in 1881.
